title: Drawing, 1960-232-1, August 14, 1888
medium: Reed pen and brown ink over graphite on cream wove paper
markings:
Watermark: "J. Whatman/Turkey Mill/1879" parallel to lower edge near the left corner,  
The mark reads from left to right in the lower right corner recto: lower line: Turkey Mill, upper line: J. Whatman, lowest line  1879. This could be the paper used for drawings of Montmajour (Heenk, Liesbeth, "Revealing van Gogh: An Examination of his Papers," The Paper Conservator, vol. 18 (1994), pp. 30,31.[kb]) (This essay is based on Heenk's dissertation/Courtauld Inst.[kb])
inscribed:
Verso:upper right in pen and gray-brown ink: No 3
Verso:upper left in graphite 4789[also an inscription which has been erased and is illegible
provenance: Ex-collection Mrs. J. van Gogh Bonger (sister-in-law of the artist), Amsterdam; Klas Fahraeus, Stockholm; Augustus T. Levinson, Copenhagen; Galerie d'Art Hugo Perls, Berlin; purchased from Perls by  Miss Edith Wetmore (The Frick Art Reference Library was informed by Mrs. Hall, Miss Wetmore's secretary [by telephone March 22, 1950], that Miss Wetmore purchased this drawing from the Hugo Perls Gallery.)
description: Rhone River scene in Arles: Two boats loaded with sand are moored by a stone quay. A man with a loaded wheelbarrow is traversing a plank gangway from one of the boats to the quay, two figures are fishing at left middleground, and two sailboats float towards a bridge on the horizon in the upper right.
